awd_titl_txt: ECDI: Computation, Communication, and Storage Infrastructure For The Roaming Edge
awd_abstract_narration:
The Wisconsin Roaming Edge (WiRE) project aims to support the development of novel and important mobile applications -- particularly those in the domain of transportation.  The key to the project is the creation of a new computing platform, termed the "roaming edge", which consists of substantial computational resources (including processors, memory, storage devices, and sensors) within mobile transportation platforms (such as busses and automobiles). The WiRE project will make these resources available to multiple applications in a secure and robust fashion, and, by providing low-latency and high-bandwidth access to data and computation, enable the creation of new classes of mobile applications. This research is about providing strong security and privacy while delivering high levels of performance. 

The WiRE project leverages recent advances in serverless computing, and four major research challenges -- the construction of a hardware-based secure execution environment, fine-grained and user-tunable privacy controls, intelligent data-driven scheduling of computation, and realistic scenario simulation for fast application prototyping.  These form the core intellectual thrusts of the work. All software will be made available via open-source licenses, thus enabling the broader community (both academic and industrial) to benefit from and contribute to the effort. The WiRE project endeavors to transform how future generations of mobile applications are developed and deployed, particularly in the emerging field of intelligent transportation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The traditional view of edge computing has centered around a smaller compute cluster (i.e., a rack of servers) deployed in various edge networks locations (e.g., collocation centers). On these racks of servers various compute, storage, and related services are deployed.

The WiRE project considers an entirely new edge computing scenario, in which the edge nodes themselves are in motion. In particular, the project focused on applications in the domain of smart transportation, where each vehicle will be equipped with a number of sensors, each of which would generate large amounts of data. Thus, in many scenarios, the only practical way to process such data would be to do the necessary analysis at what we call the roaming edge. This necessitates an end-to-end architecture and framework in which the edge compute and storage nodes are likely smaller and less capable than a typical rack of servers, are installed in highly mobile vehicles, and provide compute services for the types of data being sourced from the vehicles locally or in a neighboring area.

More concretely, the project envisions that vehicles will be equipped with a plethora of sensors. These include multiple audio-visual sensors (cameras and microphones), LIDARs (light detection and ranging) and other ranging technologies, and more. Autonomous vehicles will use such sensors to provide driving functionality, while vehicles with human drivers will use a similar, albeit perhaps a lower-resolution and less expensive, system to provide driver assistance and various other forms of guidance.

Further, once a reasonable fraction of vehicles is equipped with these sensing platforms, they can naturally become a crowd-sourced platform to gather, analyze, and organize various forms of data at city scale and beyond. However, the aggregate volume of data from each vehicle can be rather large. Even a few cameras and a LIDAR system can create hundreds of megabits per second of data. Such data cannot be easily offloaded from vehicles to the cloud for further analysis, due to lack of available network capacity from the vehicles. Thus this requires designing a computational model where analysis can be distributed across roaming edge devices to perform aggregate analysis without incurring transfer overheads.

Such platforms will naturally need to support machine-learning driven applications, as these are the basic tools for dealing with noisy input data from the real world. Thus, ML will need to be considered from the beginning of the project.

Intellectual Merit: The project makes four sets of contributions. The first is execution security for multiple tenants within the roaming-edge infrastructure. Here, the project explores modern container technology and determine its utility for the roaming edge (however, as often will occur, advances for the roaming edge may also be useful elsewhere). Second, the project develosp a roaming edge computation system, which makes scheduling and planning decisions on local and global scales to improve performance, reduce cost and data movement, and generally optimize system and application behavior. Third, the project delivers privacy preservation for applications, by providing key technologies to ensure proper privacy controls, as well as tools to better understand data lineage. Finally, the project contributed a unified lambda-based programming model, to hide the deployment complexity from application developers. Roaming edge applications will be structured in the serverless style (a.k.a., lambda-style programs), in which a large-scale application is constructed from one or more stateless functions; the infrastructure will then execute lambdas on either the roaming edge or cloud as needs dictate.


Broader impact: The project contributed to the PhD theses of over half a dozen students, and to several masters and undergraduate theses. The project ran one workshop-style class focused on edge technologies, and will reprise this course from time to time. The project also ran a ML-optimized systems seminar as related to this effort (but also jointly with Microsoft). Students also learned the state of the art and completed hands-on projects in the domain. Finally, key project findings -- at many levels -- will filter down into our undergraduate courses, too. For example, some key discoveries that were made, including in concurrency and storage hierarchy, are already being taught in undergraduate operating systems courses at UW Madison and UT Austin.


Last Modified: 02/12/2023
Modified by: Aditya Akella
